article.title: Backbone_cabal
article.paragraph: Thebackbone cabalwas an informal organization of large-siteSysopadministratorsof the worldwide distributednewsgroup-based discussion systemUsenet. It existed from about 1983 at least into the 2000s.

Thecabalwas created in an effort to facilitate reliable propagation of new Usenet posts: While in the 1970s and 1980s many news servers only operated during night time to save on the cost of long distance communication, servers of the backbone cabal were available 24 hours a day. The administrators of these servers gained sufficient influence in the otherwise anarchic Usenet community to be able to push through controversial changes, for instance theGreat RenamingofUsenetnewsgroups during 1987.
article.heading: History
article.paragraph: As Usenet has few technologically or legally enforced hierarchies, just about the only ones that formed weresocial hierarchysocial. People acquired power through persuasion(both publicly and privately), public debate, force of will (often via aggressiveflaming (Internet)flames), garnering authority and respect by spending much time and effort contributing to the community (by being a maintainer of aFAQ, for example; see alsoJames ParryKibo, etc.).

Credit for organizing the backbone about 1983 is commonly attributed toGene SpaffordGene "Spaf" Spafford,The Great Renaming FAQalthough it is also claimed byMary Ann Horton.Waybackhttp://www.maryannhorton.com/MaryAnnHorton-extended.htmlMary Ann Horton's Resum√©20010207Other prominent members of the cabal wereBrian Reid (computer scientist)Brian Reid, Richard Sexton,Chuq von Rospach, Neil Crellin andRick Adams (Internet pioneer)Rick Adams.
article.heading: In Internet culture
article.paragraph: During most of its existence, the cabal (sometimes capitalized) steadfastly denied its own existence; those involved would often respond"There is no Cabal"(sometimes abbreviated as"TINC"), whenever the existence or activities of the group were speculated on in public. It is sometimes used humorously to dispel cabal-like organizational conspiracy theories, or as an ironic statement, indicating one who knows the existence of "the cabal" will invariably deny there is one.

This belief became a model for various conspiracy theories about various Cabals with dark nefarious objectives beginning with taking over Usenet or the Internet.Website spoofingSpoofsinclude the"Eric Conspiracy"of moustachioed hackers named "Eric"; ex-members of theP.H.I.R.M.; and theLumber Cartelputatively funding anti-spammingspamefforts to support the paper industry.

The result of this policy was an aura of mystery, even a decade after the cabal mailing list disbanded in late 1988 following an internal fight.cite webhttp://www.techweb.com/encyclopedia/defineterm.jhtml?termbackbone cabalTechWeb2007-09-07http://web.archive.org/web/20070927000916/http://www.techweb.com/encyclopedia/defineterm.jhtml?term2007-09-27
